articles.title: About Us
articles.contents:
Who Are We?
The Walnut Hills
Programming Club, a chapter of INTERalliance meets on
Tuesday’s from 3-4pm in room 3104 to create projects and teach technical
skills to students.
Our club is a way for students to get hands-on programming,
organizational, and leadership experience. Students collaborate to write
code and create designs for games, websites, and more. Members create
and run club events and attend INTERalliance chapter events as well as
participate in programming competitions.
Why Join?
We want to get as many Walnut students, grades 7-12, into tech as
possible. No prior coding or design experience is
necessary.
From complete beginners to more experienced artists and programmers,
all club members participate on teams based on their level of experience
and area of interest. In addition, Programming Club works to share
excitement with the greater Walnut community through workshops and other
projects. Our projects like Walnut.Direct
aim to positively impact the Walnut community.
Our School
Walnut Hills High School
is a college preparatory school for students in grades 7-12 in
Cincinnati, Ohio. In addition to Programming Club, Walnut offers computer
science and design courses, all of which are great resources for
Walnut students who are interested in these fields.
Meet our 2022-23 Leadership
Team!
President: Annie Laursen



Annie Lausen is a
junior at WHHS and this will be her third year as a member of
Programming Club! When she’s not coding, she enjoys running and singing
in choir.
Vice President: Marie Flessa



Marie Flessa is a junior at WHHS and this is her
second year in Programming Club! Outside of the computer lab, she enjoys
baking, running, and playing lacrosse.
Competition Code
Director: Tejas Mundhe



Tejas Mundhe is a
sophomore at Walnut Hills High School who has been a part of the
programming club for the last two years. Outside of school he enjoys
robotics, swimming, reading, and playing video games.
Club Project Director: Aabha
Phadke



Aabha Phadke is a junior at WHHS. This is her first
year as a member of Programming Club, but she has gained outside
experience in coding through classes. She enjoys dancing, swimming, and
science!
Treasurer: Raghav Gangatirkar



Raghav Gangatirkar
is a junior at Walnut Hills High School and this will be his second year
in programming club. He also rows for CJRC. Outside of school, he likes
to read and fly his drone.
Design Director: Arnav Shukla



Arnav Shukla is a junior at Walnut and this is his
first year in Programming Club. He loves running, playing the tabla, and
cooking!

articles.title: Events
articles.contents:
Calendar
Below is our club calendar for the 2022-23 school year. Feel free to
explore and add these to your own calendar.



Upcoming Events
TechOlympics- February 19-20th



TechOlympics is a high school
programming convention by INTERalliance that runs for
one weekend in February. The club works on creating a project to present
at the convention throughout the year. During the event, a small group
will break off to present the project to a panel of judges. During the
rest of the convention there is tons of fun opportunities for students
to have fun at. These activities include, but are not limited to,
WikiRaces, Code Golf, Jeopardy, Jackbox Games, and more. The convention
also has many presentations by people in the work force about a wide
array of topics. All in all, this is the pinnacle event of the year that
you shouldn’t miss.
IT Expo-
April 12th



ITExpo is a small science fair
like activity put on by the University of Cincinnati in early April to
showcase projects that high school and college students have been
working on throughout the year. This club attends ITExpo to showcase the
same project we worked on for TechOlympics.

articles.title: Our Portfolio
articles.contents:
Walnut.Direct



Walnut.Direct (our 2020
showcase project) gives students straightforward directions between
rooms in our large, confusing school. It uses room-finder,
a library we created for using Dijkstra’s algorithm to generate
directions between rooms in a building.
No Lab Physics



Walnut Hills Programming Club’s 2021 showcase project. No Lab Physics allows
students and teachers to create their own custom physics labs.
E-Card-Nomics



Due to a lack of financial literacy in high school curriculum, we
have noticed that the majority of high school students (including
ourselves) do not feel confident in their financial skills going into
adulthood. We hope that E-Card-Nomics will help students
find a fun and engaging way to learn financial skills that will help
them in the future. Our project is unique in that it is free, designed
with high school students in mind, and incorporated game elements in
order to help make the experience more engaging and entertaining for
students.
